statement:
Every finite dimensional normed vector space is a Banach space.

*Proof.* Suppose $(V,\Vert\cdot\Vert)$ is the normed vector space, and
$(e_i)_{i=1}^N$ is a basis for $V$. For $x=\sum_{j=1}^N \lambda_j e_j$,
we can then define
$$\Vert x \Vert' = \sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^N |\lambda_j|^2}$$ whence
$\Vert\cdot\Vert'\colon V\to {\mathbb{R}}$ is a norm for $V$. Since ,
there is a constant $C>0$ such that
$$\frac{1}{C} \Vert x \Vert' \le \Vert x \Vert \le C \Vert x \Vert', \quad x\in V.$$
To prove that $V$ is a Banach space, let $x_1,x_2,\ldots$ be a Cauchy
sequence in $(V,\Vert\cdot \Vert)$. That is, for all $\varepsilon>0$
there is an $M\ge 1$ such that
$$\Vert x_j-x_k \Vert <\varepsilon, \ \ \mbox{for all} j,k\ge M.$$ Let
us write each $x_k$ in this sequence in the basis $(e_j)$ as
$x_k=\sum_{j=1}^N \lambda_{k,j} e_j$ for some constants
$\lambda_{k,j}\in {\mathbbmss{C}}$. For $k,l\ge 1$ we then have
$$\begin{aligned}
\Vert x_k-x_l\Vert   &\ge& \frac{1}{C} \Vert x_k-x_l \Vert' \\
   &\ge& \frac{1}{C} \sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^N |\lambda_{k,j}-\lambda_{l,j}|^2} \\
   &\ge& \frac{1}{C} |\lambda_{k,j}-\lambda_{l,j}|\end{aligned}$$ for
all $j=1,\ldots, N$. It follows that
$(\lambda_{k,1})_{k=1}^\infty, \ldots, (\lambda_{k,N})_{k=1}^\infty$ are
Cauchy sequences in ${\mathbbmss{C}}$. As ${\mathbbmss{C}}$ is complete,
these converge to some complex numbers $\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_N$.
Let $x=\sum_{j=1}^N \lambda_j e_j$.

For each $k=1,2,\ldots$, we then have $$\begin{aligned}
\Vert x-x_k\Vert &\le& C \Vert x-x_k\Vert' \\
                 &\le& C \sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^N |\lambda_{j}-\lambda_{k,j}|^2}.\end{aligned}$$
By taking $k\to \infty$ it follows that $(x_j)$ converges to $x\in V$.
$\Box$
names: every finite dimensional normed vector space is a Banach space
